summary.html:
Bookmarked How to Build Software like an SRE
Post details
I‚Äôve been doing this ‚Äúreliability‚Äù stuff for a little while now (~5 years), at companies ranging from about 20 developers to over 2,000. I‚Äôve always cared primarily about the software elements I describe as living ‚Äúoutside‚Äù the application ‚Äì like, how does it get its configuration? What kinds of instances does it run on, and are those the best kinds to use? What steps does it take on its path from ‚Äúcode in a repository‚Äù to ‚Äúrunning in production‚Äù? And I‚Äôve always kept track of what I liked ‚Äì which mechanisms allowed fast iteration and which caused frustration, which led to outages and which prevented them.

content.html: RT @abbott567 Truth bomb. The culture in most orgs is ableist. Accessibility is undervalued, underfunded and deprioritised. Specialists are disempowered, outnumbered and ignored. Middle-management would rather use their influence for exemptions than for culture change. Do better! Rant over.‚úåÔ∏è

content.html: Love to spend a good chunk writing a library for Go to wrap an http.Handler and make it straightforward to run in AWS Lambda, only to discover this morning that there's a library already for it - woops üòÖ Saves me finishing off the README or blogging about my "novel" approach, I guess

photo.alt:
Anna and Jamie standing outside their house, ahead of their friends' wedding, looking very cute.

Anna is looking beautiful  in a flowery dress, with gold shoes. She has a pair of purple heart earrings 

Jamie is in a custom made blue suit, from Black Butterfly in Nottingham, with brown shoes and mustard socks (not pictured), a bronze tie with stags on it, and a green pocket square with foxes on it.

Behind them you can see their monkey puzzle tree.

There have been discussions in the aftermath of the log4j vulnerability about whether or not open source is broken or sustainable, what we can do to improve the sustainability of the open source ecosystem moving forwards, and the entitlement of users and companies in expecting maintainers to fix their problems.

summary.html:
Listened to Kaizen! Four PRs, one big feature with Adam, Jerod & Lars Wikman (Ship It! #70)

summary.html:
Listened to Stay agile out there with Inbal Cohen (Go Time #247)
Post details
Inbal Cohen, Product expert and Agile evangelist, joins Natalie &amp; Angelica for a conversation about all things Agile. Inbal lays out some agile tips for Go devs, discusses if and how remote work changes things, describes some downsides of the methodology, and more.
